author: sky.cactus
content: The "immediate demand" is a function of cost of inclusion.  Essentially, the increase in the base fee drives demand for blockspace-at-current-price down.

author: sky.cactus
content: Eventually, the demand-at-current-price decreases until it equals half of the block size limit.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is *possible* for there to be a rapid (more than 2x) spike in demand-at-current-price, and when that happens you might miss inclusion in the next block and have to wait for a block or two, but the base fee will increase until once again the demand-at-current-price equals half of the available supply.  In times like these (which we expect to be quite rare), you may not make it into the next block despite a sufficient gas premium.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thinking in terms of apples, while everyone in the world may *want* one $0 apple, not everyone in the world wants one apple at any given price.  If you have 5 apples, you can increase the price of the apple until it reaches a point where there are only 5 people left who want it bad enough to buy an apple at that price (e.g., $1,000,000 apples).  We do the same with gas on Ethereum, increase the price until half a block's worth of gas people want to use Ethereum at the moment.

author: sky.cactus
content:
1559 does not try to nor claim to reduce gas costs.  The proper solution for that is stuff moving to layer 2 and being more efficient with what they do on layer 1.

1559 only tries to address the UX issue around gas cost estimation.
